message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute respiratory distress syndrome affects the alveolar sacs, which are responsible for gas exchange. The symptoms observed in this patient, including difficulty breathing and low oxygen saturation, are a result of damage to these cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) affects the alveolar sacs where gas exchange occurs, leading to symptoms such as severe difficulty breathing, hypoxia, and pulmonary edema. Therefore, the cells responsible for the symptoms observed in this patient are found in the alveolar sacs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is characterized by damage to the alveolar-capillary membrane, leading to increased permeability and fluid accumulation in the alveolar spaces, resulting in severe respiratory distress. Therefore, the cells responsible for the symptoms observed in this patient are found in the alveolar sacs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is caused by an inflammatory response in the alveolar sacs of the lungs. Therefore, the cells responsible for the symptoms observed in this patient are found in the alveolar sacs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute respiratory distress syndrome is caused by damage to the alveolar-capillary membrane, which leads to increased permeability and accumulation of fluid in the alveolar sacs, impairing gas exchange. Therefore, the cells responsible for the symptoms observed in this patient are found in the alveolar sacs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is characterized by inflammation and injury to the alveolar sacs, which contribute to the symptoms observed in this patient. Cells responsible for this inflammation include neutrophils and macrophages.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) involves damage to the alveolar-capillary membrane, leading to increased permeability and fluid accumulation in the alveolar spaces. This causes decreased oxygen exchange and the symptoms observed in the patient. Therefore, the cells responsible for the symptoms are found in the alveolar sacs (C).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Acute respiratory distress syndrome is characterized by damage to the alveolar capillary barrier, leading to increased permeability and accumulation of fluid in the alveolar space, resulting in impaired gas exchange and respiratory failure. Therefore, the cells responsible for the symptoms observed in this patient are found in the alveolar sacs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is diagnosed with acute respiratory distress syndrome which is characterized by injury to the alveolar-capillary membrane. Therefore, the cells responsible for the symptoms observed in this patient are found in the alveolar sacs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. ARDS is caused by injury to the alveolar-capillary membrane, leading to increased permeability and fluid accumulation in the alveolar sacs. The symptoms observed in the patient are related to this fluid accumulation in the alveolar sacs.
